text: Rather than going into the specifics, one thing I'll say about the growth system today is if you were to look at what percentage of our business comes from outbound sales, paid marketing, field, and then a bunch of other channels and then you compare it against industry benchmarks, I think the secret sauce of Ramp is not that we've found a channel that's unique and that we've over-invested or under-invested. I think what we've done differently is we've really focused on making all of those investments very much driven by technology and data.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri to break down Ramp's growth channels into a pie chart format. Sri explains that while Ramp's channel distribution isn't dramatically different from industry benchmarks, their competitive advantage lies in how they execute these channels using technology and data. He describes how Ramp has built systems to make traditional growth channels like sales and paid marketing more efficient through engineering support and automation.
text_ko: 세부로 들어가기보다는 성장 시스템에 대해 한 가지만 말씀드리면요: 우리 비즈니스에서 아웃바운드 세일즈(outbound sales), 유료 마케팅(paid marketing), 필드(field), 그 밖의 여러 채널(channel)에서 각각 차지하는 비중을 보고 업계 벤치마크(industry benchmarks)와 비교해 보면, Ramp의 비결(secret sauce)은 어떤 독특한 채널을 찾아서 거기에 과도하게 혹은 부족하게 투자했다는 게 아니에요. 저희가 다르게 해온 건 그런 모든 투자를 기술과 데이터(technology and data)로 주도되게 만드는 데 정말 집중했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我就不细说具体的了，关于我们现在的增长体系，我可以这么说：如果你看看我们从主动销售(outbound sales)、付费营销(paid marketing)、地推(field)还有其他各种渠道来的业务占比，然后跟行业基准(industry benchmarks)对比一下，我觉得Ramp的秘诀(secret sauce)不是说我们找到了什么独特的渠道，或者在某个渠道上投入过多或过少。我们做得不一样的地方是，我们特别专注于用技术和数据来驱动所有这些投入。
text_es: Más que entrar en detalles específicos, algo que te puedo decir sobre nuestro sistema de crecimiento es que si te fijas en qué porcentaje de nuestro negocio viene de ventas directas (outbound sales), marketing pagado, trabajo de campo, y otros canales, y lo comparas con los estándares de la industria, creo que la fórmula secreta de Ramp no es que hayamos encontrado un canal único donde invertimos de más o de menos. Lo que hemos hecho diferente es enfocarnos en hacer que todas esas inversiones estén muy impulsadas por tecnología y datos.

text: I think what works really well with Ramp is that we have the same shared goal, which is the pipeline driven and the payback period of the channel. It's unique to Ramp where the engineers feel ownership of the quota. They're not owning product metrics or what have you, they're obviously of course interim and input metrics that are important, but they really do feel accountable for the pipeline driven and the efficiency driven by that team.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks about Ramp's growth engineering team structure and how their goals are measured. Sri explains that their growth engineering team has a unique accountability system where engineers don't just focus on typical product metrics, but actually feel ownership for sales quotas and pipeline generation. This alignment ensures engineers work on projects that directly impact business outcomes rather than just technical metrics.
text_ko: Ramp에서 정말 잘 맞는 건 우리 모두 같은 목표를 공유한다는 거예요 — 채널의 파이프라인 중심(pipeline-driven) 운영과 채널의 투자 회수 기간(payback period)이에요. 엔지니어들이 쿼터(quota)에 대해 주인의식을 느낀다는 건 Ramp만의 독특한 점이에요. 제품 지표(product metrics)를 직접 관리하진 않지만, 중간 지표(interim metrics)나 투입 지표(input metrics) 같은 것들이 중요하다는 건 당연해요. 그럼에도 불구하고 이들은 파이프라인 중심(pipeline-driven)의 성과와 팀이 만들어내는 효율성(efficiency)에 대해 진짜 책임감을 느껴요.
text_zh: 我觉得和Ramp合作特别顺的地方就是，我们目标很一致，都是奔着渠道的pipeline(销售漏斗)和回本周期去的。Ramp比较特别的是，他们的工程师对quota(销售指标)特别有主人翁意识。他们不是只盯着产品数据啊什么的，当然那些过程指标和输入指标肯定也重要，但他们确实会为pipeline的效果和团队的效率负责任。
text_es: Creo que lo que funciona muy bien con Ramp es que tenemos el mismo objetivo en común, que es el pipeline generado y el período de retorno de la inversión del canal. Es algo único de Ramp donde los ingenieros sienten que son dueños de la cuota. No están enfocados en métricas de producto ni nada por el estilo - obviamente hay métricas intermedias y de entrada que son importantes - pero realmente se sienten responsables del pipeline generado y de la eficiencia que logra ese equipo.

text: What you see internally is what I'll say is razor-sharp focus on reducing cycle time and bias to action and how do we reduce cycle time. I think it's basically the core of it culturally to me is getting people to think about smaller units of time for decision making. It seems obvious but I think you really have to reinforce it culturally.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri to explain what Ramp's legendary velocity culture actually looks and feels like from the inside. Sri describes how Ramp maintains unprecedented product velocity by focusing intensely on reducing cycle time and creating a bias toward action. He emphasizes that the key is getting people to think in smaller time units for decision-making, though this cultural approach requires constant reinforcement.
text_ko: 사내에서 보이는 건, 제 말로 하자면 사이클 타임(cycle time)을 줄이는 데 대한 정말 날카로운 집중과 행동 편향(bias to action), 그리고 '사이클 타임을 어떻게 줄일지'에 대한 고민이에요. 제게 문화적으로 가장 핵심은 사람들이 의사결정을 더 짧은 시간 단위로 생각하게 만드는 거예요. 겉으로는 당연해 보이지만, 실제로는 그걸 조직 문화로 계속해서 강화해야 해요.
text_zh: 从内部来看，我觉得就是要超级专注地缩短决策周期(cycle time)，偏向于赶紧行动起来，怎么把这个周期时间给压缩下来。我觉得从文化上来说，核心就是要让大家习惯用更短的时间单位去做决策。听起来挺简单的，但你真得在文化层面不断强化这一点。
text_es: Lo que vemos internamente es lo que yo llamaría un enfoque súper preciso en reducir los tiempos de ciclo y esa tendencia hacia la acción - ¿cómo acortamos los plazos? Creo que básicamente el núcleo cultural para mí es lograr que la gente piense en períodos más cortos para tomar decisiones. Parece obvio, pero realmente tienes que reforzarlo como parte de la cultura.

text: I think design of the team, people often... I think it's a red herring about team structure and team design and what's the right one, et cetera. I think most of that is irrelevant. What actually matters is culture and rituals and cadences rather than the team itself.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri about his learnings on building repeatable growth engines and growth teams. Sri argues that most discussions about growth team structure and design are distractions from what really matters. He believes that culture, rituals, and cadences are far more important than the specific team composition or organizational structure when building effective growth engines.
text_ko: 저는 팀 구조(team structure)나 팀 디자인(team design), 어떤 게 옳은지 따지는 건 오히려 본질을 흐리는 얘기라고 생각해요. 실제로 중요한 건 팀 자체가 아니라 문화와 의식(rituals), 그리고 운영 리듬(cadences)이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得团队设计这个事儿，大家经常... 我觉得纠结团队架构啊、团队设计啊、什么样的结构最好啊这些，其实都是在转移注意力。我觉得这些大部分都不重要。真正重要的是文化、仪式感和节奏，而不是团队本身。
text_es: Mira, creo que el diseño de equipos, la gente muchas veces... pienso que es una distracción todo eso de la estructura del equipo y el diseño y cuál es el correcto, etcétera. Creo que la mayoría de eso no importa realmente. Lo que de verdad cuenta es la cultura y los rituales y las dinámicas (cadences) más que el equipo en sí.

text: I do think there's actually a general path that most B2B companies take and should take. My view is you start off with founder-led sales, the early team needs to know how to actually sell. Then you hire your first couple of salespeople, then you start some very low cost targeted marketing efforts. So whether it's content, community, small scale events, and then PR, after all of that is when you start paid and brand effort and then SEO probably start around the same time that you start paid marketing efforts.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri about his opinion on how to sequence different growth channels for B2B companies. Sri outlines a specific progression that he believes most B2B companies should follow, starting with founder-led sales and gradually adding more expensive and scalable channels. His reasoning is that channels become more expensive as you progress but also more effective as you learn about your customers.
text_ko: 저는 대부분의 B2B 회사들이 따라야 할 일반적인 경로가 있다고 생각해요. 제 생각에는 처음에는 창립자가 직접 판매를 하고, 초기 팀이 실제로 판매하는 방법을 알아야 해요. 그 다음에 첫 몇 명의 영업직원을 채용하고, 아주 저렴한 타겟 마케팅을 시작해야 해요. 콘텐츠, 커뮤니티, 소규모 이벤트 같은 것들이요. 그리고 PR을 진행한 후에야 유료 마케팅과 브랜드 노력을 시작하고, SEO도 아마 유료 마케팅을 시작할 때쯤에 함께 시작할 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分B2B公司其实都有一个通用的发展路径，也应该这样走。我的看法是，一开始肯定是创始人自己做销售，早期团队得知道怎么卖东西。然后你招几个销售，接着开始搞一些低成本的精准营销，比如做内容、建社群、办点小活动，再做做PR。等这些都搞定了，再开始投付费广告和品牌推广，SEO的话差不多和付费推广同时开始就行。
text_es: Creo que sí hay un camino general que la mayoría de las empresas B2B siguen y deberían seguir. Mi punto de vista es que empiezas con ventas lideradas por el fundador, el equipo inicial necesita saber cómo vender de verdad. Después contratas a tus primeros vendedores, luego arrancas con esfuerzos de marketing muy económicos y bien dirigidos. O sea, ya sea contenido, comunidad, eventos pequeños, y después relaciones públicas. Después de todo eso es cuando empiezas con los esfuerzos pagados y de marca, y luego el SEO probablemente lo inicias más o menos al mismo tiempo que arrancas con el marketing pagado.

text: Growth experiments in my history are typically 30%-ish success rate. So the vast majority of things that you try don't work. And so you want to create a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks and aren't afraid to fail. And for me, failure is not that you didn't drive revenue, failure is not learning.
speaker: Sri Batchu
context: Lenny asks Sri to explain his concept of failing conclusively rather than just failing fast in experiments. Sri explains that most growth experiments fail (around 70% failure rate), so it's crucial to create a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks. He redefines failure - it's not about missing revenue targets, but about failing to learn from the experiment, which is why designing tests properly is essential.
text_ko: 제가 해온 성장 실험(growth experiments)은 보통 성공률(success rate)이 한 30% 정도였어요. 그래서 시도하는 것들 대부분은 잘 안 돼요. 사람들이 위험을 감수하고 실패하는 걸 두려워하지 않는 문화를 만들어야 해요. 제게 실패란 수익을 못 냈다는 게 아니라, 그로부터 배우지 못한 거예요.
text_zh: 我做过的增长实验(growth experiments)成功率一般也就30%左右。也就是说，你尝试的大部分东西都不会成功。所以你得营造一种文化，让大家不怕冒险，不怕失败。在我看来，失败不是说你没带来收入，失败是你什么都没学到。
text_es: En mi experiencia, los experimentos de crecimiento suelen tener una tasa de éxito de alrededor del 30%. O sea, la gran mayoría de las cosas que pruebas no funcionan. Por eso necesitas crear una cultura donde la gente no tenga miedo de arriesgarse ni de fallar. Para mí, fallar no es que no generes ingresos, fallar es no aprender nada.
